words.w: 2. تَحْتَ "under". The noun following تَحْتَ is in the genitive case because it is mudaf ilaihi: تَحْتَ المَكْتَبِ، تَحْتَ الكِتَابِ
3. يَا is a vocative particle. A noun following يَا has only one dammah: يَا أُسْتَاذُ، يَا شَيْخُ، يَا بِلآلُ not  يَا بِلآلٌ etc.
4. The words اِسْمٌ and اِبْنٌ commence with hamzatu l-wasl. When preceded by a word the initial <<i>> is dropped in pronunciation.

اِسْمُ  الْوَلَدِ  بِلآلٌ 
 ism-u l-walad-i bilal-u-n 
وَاسْمُ  الْبِنْتِ  آمِنَةُ 
wa sm-u l-bint-i aminat-u
اِبْنُ الْمُدَرِّسِ طَبِيْبٌ 
ibn-u l-mudarris-i tabib-u-n
وَابْنُ  الإِمَمِ  يَاجِرٌ 
wa bn-u l-imam-i tajir-u-n
أَيْنَ  ابْنُ  حَامِدٍ 
aina bn-u hamid-i-n?
